assets.asset: Two boys walking at sunset in Ratna park in Kathmandu.Ratna Park is a gathering place for gay men. They try to stay discreet as homosexuality is not socially acceptable in Nepal. The alienation of gay men contributes to the spread of HIV in the country.

Amrit and a friend in Ratna Park. Gay men are frowned upon by the Nepalese society. They need to hide and have few meeting places. A lot meet in Ratna Park through such gatherings.Amrit often come to Ratna to dsitribute condoms, part of a HIV prevention programme of a NGO he works for.

Divya with 2 other transgender friends. At 17, Divya was sold to a brothel in Bombay. After working 5 years there she found out she was HIV positive. She was rejected from the brothel and later from her village. She now fights for the rights of transgenders in Nepal and is a member of Blue Diamond Society a local NGO.

Deepyka and her friends chatting with apotential client a Thamel tea shop. Deepyka, 19 years old, is an orphan and left her hometown to find a living in Kathmandu. She started prostitution at teh age of 15 and is HIV positive. She receives care and support from the NGO Blue Diamond Society and gets an antiretrovitral therapy.
On the sidewalks of Thamel, a transgender sex worker facing potential clients.
Two hostesses chatting with a security guard outside a gogo-bar in the Thamel area of Kathmandu.
Biju a drug user, in his room, injecting himself Norphin, an addictive painkiller widely used in Nepal as a cheap replacement for heroin.
Drug addicts helping each others to inject Norphin, an addictive pain killer cheaper than heroin. They are struggling to fight a blood vessel.
At Tekku hospital a visitor having his blood taken for HIV testing.

Residents of Nava Kiran + outside the building. One of them has a tattoo made signalling his HIV status. The hospice has about 50 residents 20 of which receive a anti-retroviral therapy and 5 are treated for tuberculosis. Nava Kiran + is a NGo run by former drug users focussing on drug users and on HIV prevention, access to therapy, rehabilitation of addicts.

At Nava Kiran + hospice, Joti (30 years old) in her bed during the distribution of antiretroviral drugs. She suffers from various HIV related infections and walk with difficulties. She got contaminated with HIV by her husband a migrant worker.

Sunil feeding Pancha Maya on her bed at Nava Kiran + hospice under the eyes of Bal. Pancha maya came back a few days earlier from Tekku Hospital where she underwent surgery. She arrived one month earlier at the hospice suffering from multiple HIV related infections. Sunil an ex-drug user lives at the hospice and does some voluntary work there. The hospice has about 50 residents 20 of which receive a anti-retroviral therapy and 5 are treated for tuberculosis. Nava Kiran + is a NGO run by former drug users focussing on drug users and on HIV prevention, access to therapy, rehabilitation of addicts.
Narayan at Blue Diamond Society hospice. His father brought him there a few days earlier as he was weaken by several infections. Narayan is a migrant worker.
At Tekku hospital Narayan is waiting to have his blood tested for HIV and other infections. He is sitting by a listing of all the tests perormed at the hospital and their respective costs.
Bal weariing a "HIV positive" T-shirt has just cleaned his room where Ramchandra suffering from tuberculosis is lying in bed. Bal is a former drug user.
Suman carrying Bijay to the aids ward of Tekku hospital. Bijay a former drug user is suffering from HIV related pulmonary infection. He died a few hours after his arrival at the hospital.

At Tekku hopsital aids ward, Amit (right) is staring at Bijay who just arrived. and is in pain. Both are former drug users. Amit is treated for anemia while Bijay suffers from a pulmonary infection. Since he arrived 10 days earlier, Amit has seen a few patients dying. Bijay died a few hours after his arrival at the hospital.
At Tekku hospital aids ward, a patient on his bed.
At Tekku hospital aids ward, Bijay, a HIV positive former drug user is lying on his bed. He died a few hours after this picture was taken.
